newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan tightens rules on China investment.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan tightens rules on China investment.

text.p: Taipei on Wednesday announced new restrictions on Taiwan's investments in rival China, including a US$50 million project cap, but vowed to drop the rules if Beijing renounces the right to retake the island by force.

"At a time when cross-strait (Taiwan-China) relations are so tense, we do not wish to have overly large investments or public construction investments" in the Chinese mainland, economics minister Wang Chih-kang told a news conference.
"But if the Chinese communists announce they are giving up the right to use military force to solve cross-strait problems, I myself believe the restrictions should be dropped," he said.

Under the new rules, effective July 1, Taiwan firms are explicitly forbidden to invest in mainland infrastructure projects such as railways, roads and power plants -- throwing up a new obstacle to Formosa Plastics Group's planned US$3 billion mainland power station.
The ministry said it also had set a ceiling of US$50 million on single-project investments by Taiwan interests.
Total investments by any single firm listed in Taiwan's main or over-the-counter stock exchange would vary according its size but no single project could exceed the cap, the ministry said.
Taiwan has banned direct investment and trade with China since a civil war split them in 1949.

Since a political thaw began in the late 1980s, some 30,000 Taiwan firms have poured over US$30 billion into the mainland -- routing their investments through third countries. As a result, Taiwan has become one of China's top overseas investors and China one of Taiwan's most important markets.
Communist China regards Nationalist-ruled Taiwan as a rebel-held province that must be brought under mainland sovereignty, preferably through peaceful means but by force of arms if necessary.
